Dialog.text: This is Basilisk. Hello?
This is Basilisk to KASMA Module Thirteen. We are sending two classified pieces of technology we recovered from TranStar's moonbase.
They should be arriving in a few moments.
We could reassign you to a new post.
Or... I could give you a mission that would have you out of that blackbox in under week.
I have your attention?
There's a transport set to rendezvous with your position. It's carrying two pieces of technology that originated from the TranStar moonbase before it went dark.
One is an operator containing a backup of the base. It's a simulation of all the research data, company secrets and connectomes from employee brains.
We picked you because it's protected by a *lot* of encryption.
Fortunately, it comes with a Looking Glass Visor so you'll be able to search the sim visually.
You'll be plugging into the moonbase as it was...seeing it through the personnel that were stationed there.
Oh, and, congratulations. I am pleased to inform you that executing these orders will fulfill your contract.
After you recover the data, we're going to pick you up. So, great news. You'll be with family soon.
[people talking in the background]
Basilisk to KASMA Module Thirteen. Copy please.
Good hunting, Interceptor.
Ok, M-13, you're the expert... the delivery is docking now so, I'll leave you to it.
Module Thirteen? Hello - I'm very sorry you're waking up to this.
This is Basilisk to Module Thirteen.
M-13, this is Basilisk.
Repeating: Basilisk to KASMA Module Thirteen. Copy please.
[background noises]
Dialog.notes: SFX - sound of coms opening, garbled static, background voices. From the background din, one voice floats to the surface, becoming clearer

Dialog.text: Peter, are you there?
Basilisk to Module Thirteen...
I'm just checking the oxygen levels since the impact. Can you please run a diagnostic on the scrubbers? There should be a workstation. I'm powering it up now.
It's self-explanatory.
Peter, this has to be short.
Ah, you're ok. Congratulations. It seems the simulation is significantly corrupted but scans of your brain tomography indicate no damage.
The corruption appears to be limited to the host Operator...no externalization - so you should be fine.
We've transmitted an app that should help track the simulation's instability.
This is Basilisk. Orbital intercept M-13 tells us there is elevated activity on all TranStar security channels.
We think you've been compromised.
We need you to destroy all evidence of your operations.
I'll contact you soon with further instructions.
Good hunting.
Alright, Claire.
Please install it immediately so you are not caught unaware again.
Basilisk out.
Don't let those virtual deaths get you down.
Everyone here is very happy with your progress so, O.C. thought it appropriate to authorize some mail from home.
I sent it to your workstation.
I have engineering here. They say not to worry. Damage to oxygen systems is minor. And it is going to hold longer than you'll need.
So, gravity loss is probably the more annoying bit at the moment. But I'm told you can run a diagnostic that will re-calibrate the stabilizers.
You'll find the interface behind a hatch in the ceiling.
[background voices]
Also, yes, the cause was 'small-debris impact'. Much less than a centimeter. You're going to be fine.
Basilisk out.
...ok, Teddy. Well, it's just *a bit* cold!
I suppose.
He has a family, yes? At least their future will be decent.
I suppose. You're probably right.
Yes. I'm good. You're right.
Yes, right. Ok. Thanks.
What is... ? [sound of fumbling with controls, beeps]
Test. Test. Is this on? Module Thirteen? Hello? [fumbling noises]
Dialog.notes: SFX - <sound of additional fumbling and beeps, then the connection goes dead.>

Dialog.text: Look, I need to talk to you. Everything passing between the module and KASMA is logged, so I know the channel was open. And I know what you heard. Right now, I'm the only one who knows.
I need to say I'm sorry. You're not the only one who signed a penalty contract with KASMA and many of us are obligated to the company now in difficult ways.
I can't paint this a different color for you. But if you help me, if you finish what the company is asking you to do, I will personally provide you with an out.
If you don't trust me, I don't blame you. But if you don't trust me now, both of us will be in the same shit.
I leave it to you to decide. I have to go now.
Please consider what I've said, Peter. For you... and me... and your family.
Basilisk out.
I've unlocked a utility on your workstation per our agreement.
I want to thank you for all you've done.
You don't have much time so, good luck to you.
Good luck.

Dialog.notes: I've got something terrible to say. TS to Cl

Dialog.text: I'm very sorry. O.C. is... they're saying they can't dedicate any assets for a dustoff. And I... there's just nothing I can do. I'm sorry.
Dialog.notes: Trying to explain. Frustrated. Angry at her superiors. TS to Claire

Dialog.text: You're on your own.
This is the last time I'm allowed to contact you.
Basilisk out.
Dialog.notes: Angry sign off. TS to Cl

Dialog.text: We've learned that Director Yu is planning to duplicate her personality onto an Operator using TranStar's emulation tech.
We need you to install a program on her workstation so that when she does this it will be... terminal. It'll look like an accident.
Your command key has all the necessary functions.
We're still working on an exit strategy for you. I'm sorry - everyone is scrambling up here. We've lost contact with our assets on Talos I.
I'm sure things aren't much better on the moon.
Good job, Claire.
Okay, last step - when Riley launches the Operator, we plan on scooping it up. We need a way to track it, so O.C. wants you to hide your command key inside the Operator.
It should have a compartment.
That's it. We're going to get you out of there.
Dialog.notes: Straining to convince Claire... herself? TS to Cl

Dialog.text: Basilisk out.
O.C. is fairly certain she'll launch the operator as an emergency measure, afterwards.
We need you to hide your command key on that operator.
Your key has a few programs that will hijack the emulation process and make the experience... terminal.
It'll look like an accident.
And then, when the operator launches we'll scoop it up.
There's a lot to do. I'm sending your orders along so you can check them off as you go.
It looks like you're just about a quarter of the way through the orders we sent you.
Don't forget to keep checking them. You can see your orders from the ready room or from within the simulation itself.
Just checking in.
You have only one order remaining. What you've accomplished... it's incredible. This last one is going to be tough.
But once it's done, your contract is fulfilled. You'll have no further obligation to KASMA... nor will KASMA have any to you.
You understand? Just be sure... I - just make sure you're ready. For your last order, I mean.
That's all I wanted to say.
Basilisk out.
Oh and good work.
You're over half-way done now.
You're nearly half-way done now.
Keep knocking those orders out and you'll be with your family in no time.
You making great progress with your orders.
It looks like you're just over a quarter of the way through the orders we sent you.
